Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is in the area of number theory. Number theory has its historical roots in the study of natural numbers. It is among the oldest branches of mathematics. Within the last half century it has become an indispensable tool in diverse applications in areas such as data transmission and processing, and communication systems.

The proposal centers on the theory of automorphic forms. The main goal of the proposal is to establish a quantitative refinement of the Gross-Prasad conjecture, in the special case of Whittaker functionals. The conjecture can be viewed as a far-reaching local to global principle for period integrals. The PI will also extend the techniques developed to study the general case of Gross-Prasad conjecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project is to study Whittaker-Fourier coefficients of automorphic forms. Previously with E. Lapid we made conjectures about the relation of these coefficients with L-values. These conjectures are in the framework of more general Gan-Gross-Prasad conjectures relating period integrals (which are analytic objects) and L-values (arithmetic objects).

We (with E. Lapid) developed a strategy in proving the conjectures using Ginzburg-Rallis-Soudry's automorphic descent method. We proved the conjectured identities in the case of automorphic forms on the metaplectic groups. This generalized Waldspurger's work on Fourier coefficients of half-integral weight modular forms. We also made progress for the case of other classical groups. In the case of unitary groups, we reduced the problem to a set of local identites and provided a formal proof in low rank cases. These ideas were further develped by K. Morimoto to complete the proof. For orthogonal and symplectic groups, we also developed the ideas for a formal proof, however making the formal proof rigorous is a stumbling block at the moment.

As a byproduct, we (together with E. Lapid and A. Ichino) proved Hiraga-Ichino-Ikeda's conjecture on formal degrees for the odd orthogonal groups and metaplectic groups. We also developed results on local harmonic analysis, distinguished representations and theta correspondence along the way.

In a work with M. Longo, we proved a generalization of Kohnen's result relating Shintani integrals of integral weight forms and Fourier coefficients of half integral weight forms, and used the generalization to establish a conjecture of Darmon and Tornaria in the theory of p-adic L-functions.

During the award period, PI served as graduate director in his department, organized (with Y. Sakellaridis) annual Junior Number Theory Days workshop--each year 12-14 graduating Ph.Ds or new postdocs are invited to present their work. PI adviced visiting postdocs, volunteered to teach middle school kids competition level math on weekends. PI together with other math enthusiasts developed a website mathcup.com, aimed at 3-8 grade students interested in challenging math problems.
